questions.text: Which of the following is the most common, preventable cause of mental retardation?
questions.solution:
Congenital hypothyroidism is the most common preventable cause of mental retardation which results from a deficient production of thyroid hormone. It is more common among girls and the prevalence is about 1:3000 to 1:4000 births.

Down's syndrome is the most common overall cause of mental retardation, followed by Fragile X syndrome, which mainly affects boys.

 

 

Causes of mental retardation:
Prenatal

Congenital hypothyroidism

Infection (toxoplasma, rubella, CMV, HSV)

Genetic abnormalities

  • Trisomy 21
  • Fragile X syndrome
  • other point mutations and chromosomal abnormalities

Toxins and teratogens

  • Alcohol
  • Drugs
  • Radiation

Inborn errors of metabolism
Perinatal

Hypoxia

Prematurity

Intracranial haemorrhage

Perinatal CNS infection
Postnatal

Acquired brain injury

CNS infection, haemorrhage, malignancy

Severe malnutrition and deprivation

Environmental toxins (lead, mercury)

questions.text: In a 4-month old, term infant with open posterior fontanelle and hypotonia, you suspect congenital hypothyroidism and send thyroid studies. Which of the following is the most common cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Thyroid dysgenesis is the most common cause of permanent congenital hypothyroidism (80–85% of cases) > dyshormonogenesis (15%).

Dysgenesis may involve ectopy, agenesis (absence) or hypoplasia (underdevelopment) of the thyroid gland. Dyshormonogenesis results from a defect in any of the steps in thyroid hormone biosynthesis.

Etiology of congenital hypothyroidism:

Primary hypothyroidism:

  • Thyroid dysgenesis
  • Thyroid dyshormonogenesis
  • Iodine deficiency (endemic goiter)
  • Defect in thyroid hormone transport- Mutation in MCT8 (monocarboxylate
    transporter 8) gene
  • Maternal antibodies- thyrotropin receptor–blocking antibody
    (TRBAb)
  • Maternal medications- iodides, amiodarone, propylthiouracil, methimazole, radioiodine

Central (hypopituitary) hypothyroidism:

  • TSH deficiency- mutation in TSH β-subunit gene
  • TRH  deficiency- mutation in TRH gene
  • TRH unresponsiveness- mutation in TRH receptor gene
  • Multiple congenital pituitary hormone deficiencies

*TSH - thyroid-stimulating hormone; TRH - thyroid-releasing hormone

Acquired hypothyroidism can be caused by iodine deficiency, thyroiditis, radiation, histiocytosis, and drugs. The most common cause of acquired hypothyroidism is autoimmune thyroiditis (Hashimoto's).

Note: Mutation in PAX-8 gene is associated with congenital hypothyroidism and genitourinary abnormalities such as renal agenesis.

questions.text: You are called to see a 3-day-old, term neonate, who has not passed meconium yet. On clinical examination, there is generalized hypotonia and the abdomen is slightly distended without any evidence of ascites or hepatosplenomegaly. Incidentally, you also note a palpable goitre in this baby. Laboratory investigations reveal low T4 and elevated TSH levels. Which of the following is the most likely cause for this child's condition?
questions.solution:
A history of decreased activity and late passage of meconium, associated with low T4 and high TSH is suggestive of primary hypothyroidism. In an infant with a palpable goitre, the likely diagnosis is congenital hypothyroidism secondary to thyroid dyshormonogenesis. 

The most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism is thyroid dysgenesis but it is not associated with goitre. Thyroid dyshormonogenesis results from the deficiency of one or more enzymes involved in thyroid hormone synthesis/secretion.

Congenital hypothyroidism can be:

Goitrous (Palpable goitre) Non-goitrous (No palpable goitre)

Thyroid dyshormonogenesis

Iodine deficiency

Placental passage of antithyroid drugs

Thyroid dysgenesis

Thyroid receptor blocking antibodies

Central (hypopituitary) hypothyroidism

questions.text: At how many weeks of gestation does thyroxine secretion begin in a fetus?
questions.solution:
Thyroxine secretion begins in the fetus at 12 weeks of gestation.

The fetal thyroid arises from an outpouching of the foregut at the base of the tongue (foramen cecum). It migrates to its normal location over the thyroid cartilage by 8-10 wk of gestation. The bilobed shape of the thyroid is recognized by 7 weeks of gestation.

questions.text: An anxious mother has brought a 4-month-old baby with complaints that the baby is not feeding well and is excessively sleepy all the time. Clinical examination reveals jaundice and hypotonia. His picture is provided below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above picture shows a child with a protuberant abdomen, umbilical hernia, macroglossia, and edematous facies. Also, the infant is sluggish, has jaundice, feeding difficulties, and hypotonia, all of which suggests a diagnosis of congenital hypothyroidism.

Clinical features of congenital hypothyroidism:

  • Prolongation of physiologic hyperbilirubinemia- early sign (it is due to delayed maturation of glucuronide conjugation)
  • Constipation- usually does not respond to treatment
  • Wide open anterior and posterior fontanelles (>0.5 cm) and cranial sutures
  • Developmental delay, delayed bone growth, delayed dentition
  • Cardiovascular- slow pulse rate, cardiomegaly, asymptomatic pericardial effusion, edema
  • Respiratory- macroglossia, feeding difficulties, choking spells, respiratory difficulties
  • Haematological- macrocytic anaemia refractory to treatment with haematinics
  • Nervous system- hypothermia, hypotonia, slow relaxation of deep tendon reflexes, sluggishness, and somnolence

questions.text: A newborn with abnormal neonatal screening tests was diagnosed with Pendred syndrome. Which of the following is not a feature of this syndrome?
questions.solution:
Sensorineural hearing loss is present in Pendred syndrome; not conductive hearing loss.

Pendred syndrome is an autosomal-recessive disorder, caused by a mutation in the gene SLC26A4 on chromosome 7, which codes for pendrin, a chloride–iodide transport protein common to the thyroid gland and the cochlea. 

Clinical features include sensorineural hearing loss and goitre with hypothyroidism. It is the most common cause of syndromic deafness. The biochemical reason for hypothyroidism in patients with Pendred syndrome is impaired iodide organification (resulting from a mutation in the Pendrin gene).

questions.text: A 9-day-old infant has elevated TSH level and low T4 level on newborn screening. If this condition is left untreated, which of the following is most likely to be seen in this infant in the first few months of life?
questions.solution:
Elevated TSH levels and low T4 levels in a 9-day-old infant are suggestive of congenital hypothyroidism. Prolongation of physiologic hyperbilirubinemia is an early sign of congenital hypothyroidism. It is due to delayed maturation of the hepatic glucuronide conjugation system.

Hyperreflexia, hyperirritability and diarrhoea are seen in hyperthyroidism; not hypothyroidism.

Note:

Kocher–Debré–Sémélaigne syndrome: The muscles are usually hypotonic in congenital hypothyroidism. Rarely, hypothyroidism in infancy can be characterized by generalized muscular pseudohypertrophy, myxoedema, short stature and cretinism. Affected older children can have an athletic appearance. Boys are more prone to the development of the syndrome.

questions.text: During a rural health camp, a father brings a dull-looking baby with macroglossia and an umbilical hernia. On enquiry, you find out that the parents were told about a thyroid problem in the child at birth, for which they did not pursue any treatment. Which of the following is least likely to be found in children with the given condition?
questions.solution:
A dull-looking face with macroglossia, and umbilical hernia in a child with a thyroid disorder are all indicative of congenital hypothyroidism. Craniosynostosis is not seen in neonatal hypothyroidism. It is seen in hyperthyroidism.

Craniosynostosis refers to the premature fusion of sutures and closure of fontanelles and often results in abnormal, triangular facies. In congenital hypothyroidism, there is delayed closure of the fontanelles. Palpable goitre, though not common, can be seen in cases of untreated thyroid dyshormonogenesis.

questions.text: As part of a quality improvement project undertaken by the maternal and child health services, you are evaluating the current practice of newborn screening and detection rates of hypothyroidism in various community health centres. Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Simultaneous measurement of T4 and TSH levels is the ideal method.
The sample is obtained by heel-prick between 1-5 days of life using dried blood spot.
Newborn screening always detects the affected twin in same-sex twins.
Primary TSH, with back up T4 is the most common strategy used.

questions.solution:
Newborn screening can fail to detect the affected twin with hypothyroidism.

Discordance for thyroid dysgenesis is the rule in monozygotic twins. The transfusion of euthyroid blood from the unaffected twin normalizes the serum levels of T4 and TSH in the affected twin, resulting in delayed or missed diagnoses. Therefore, a second sample for congenital hypothyroidism screening at 14 days of age should be considered in monozygotic twins. 

Neonatal thyroid screening strategies:

  • Primarily TSH, backup T4; T4 is measured if TSH level is >20 mU/L
  • Primarily T4, backup TSH: TSH is measured only if T4 level is low
  • Concomitant T4 and TSH; it is the most sensitive method

Note: the sample is obtained after 24-48 hours, to minimize the false elevation of TSH values due to normal post-delivery neonatal TSH surge.

questions.text: As an intern posted in paediatrics, you are asked to interpret the results of a heel prick test that you performed on a newborn. Which of the following results is suggestive of primary hypothyroidism?

choices.text: Low T4 level and low TSH level
Low T4 level and high TSH level
High T4 level and low TSH level
High T4 level and high TSH level

questions.solution:
Low T4 and high TSH levels indicate primary hypothyroidism.

Blood specimen for neonatal thyroid screening is obtained by heel prick between 1 and 5 days of life.

Levothyroxine therapy is started immediately after diagnosis, at 10 to 15 µg/kg per day.

Condition Goitre T4 TSH
Thyroid dysgenesis Absent Low Elevated
Thyroid dyshormonogenesis Present Low Elevated
Thyroid receptor blocking antibodies Absent Low Elevated
Central hypothyroidism Absent Low Normal/Low
Hyperthyroidism Present High Low

questions.text: The image given below depicts an x-ray of the knee in a term baby. Which among the following conditions is associated with it?
questions.solution:
The deformity shown in the X-ray image is the absence of distal femoral epiphysis, which is a typical radiological feature of congenital hypothyroidism.

X-ray findings in hypothyroidism

  • Absence of distal femoral and proximal tibial epiphyses at birth.
  • Punctate epiphyseal dysgenesis (multiple foci of ossification)
  • Deformity or beaking of the 12th thoracic or 1st or 2nd lumbar vertebra
  • X-ray image of the skull shows large fontanels and wide sutures; wormian (intrasutural) bones; and, often, an enlarged and round sella turcica.

questions.text: Ayesha is a 9th standard girl who presented with a neck swelling, which began more than a year ago. Her mother says she is embarrassed about it and always covers her neck with a shawl when she goes to school. Her menstrual cycles have also become irregular as of late. Blood tests reveal slightly elevated TSH levels and the presence of thyroid peroxidase antibodies.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of thyroid peroxidase antibodies (TPO-Abs) and elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level in a child with a goitre is suggestive of chronic lymphocytic (Hashimoto) thyroiditis.

Chronic lymphocytic (Hashimoto) thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease. Clinical presentation can include goitre, growth retardation, and other features of hypothyroidism. The thyroid is diffusely enlarged, firm, and non-tender.

TSH is moderately elevated and TPO-Abs and anti-thyroglobulin antibodies (anti-Tg Abs) can be detected.

questions.text: A lady, with a history of a thyroid disorder and three prior abortions, delivered a female neonate prematurely at 34 weeks of gestation. In the newborn infant, tachycardia, irritability, and prominent eyes were noted and neonatal hyperthyroidism was suspected.  Which of the following statements is false about the condition?

choices.text: Maternal Graves' disease is the most common cause of neonatal hyperthyroidism
It results from the transplacental passage of maternal stimulatory TSH receptor antibody
Microcephaly and frontal bossing with triangular facies are common clinical findings
Neonatal hyperthyroidism occurs in most infants born to mothers with a history of Graves’ disease

questions.solution:
Neonatal hyperthyroidism occurs in only about 2% of infants born to mothers with a history of Graves’ disease. But maternal Graves' disease is by far the most common cause of neonatal hyperthyroidism.

Neonatal hyperthyroidism (due to Grave's) results from the transplacental passage of maternal stimulatory thyrotropin/TSH receptor antibody (TSHR-Ab).

Clinical features are as follows:

  • Low birth weight (IUGR)
  • Premature birth
  • Microcephaly
  • Frontal bossing and triangular facies
  • Warm, moist skin
  • Irritability, hyperactivity, restlessness, poor sleep
  • Tachycardia

Note:

TSHR-Ab (TSH-R-stimulating antibodies) is another name for TSH-R-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI).

questions.text: A pregnant woman with a past history of Grave's disease has currently completed 36 weeks of gestation. She underwent partial thyroidectomy 10 years back and has remained euthyroid since then. The previous child had craniosynostosis. Which of the following antibodies is most likely to be detected, if a cord blood sampling is done at delivery?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a history of Graves' disease in the mother and craniosynostosis (neonatal Graves') in the previous child suggests that the fetus is at increased risk of neonatal Grave's disease. Thus, the antibody likely to be found at birth in the cord blood sampling is the TSH receptor stimulating antibody (TRSAb).

Neonatal Graves is caused by the transplacental passage of TRSAbs from a mother with a history of Graves' disease. The mothers can have 

  • Active Graves' disease
  • Graves' in remission
  • Prior history of Graves' treated with radioactive ablation or thyroidectomy

TSRAbs bind to the receptor for TSH and stimulate cyclic AMP, leading to thyroid hyperplasia and unregulated overproduction of thyroid hormone.

Related Pearl: Antibodies seen in some autoimmune thyroid disorders

Antibody Disorder
TSH receptor-stimulating Immunoglobulins (TSI) Graves disease
Anti TPO & Anti Tg antibodies Chronic lymphocytic(Hashimoto) thyroiditis

TRBAb

(maternal transmission)

 Transient congenital hypothyroidism (maternal autoimmune thyroid disease)
  • Anti TPO – Anti thyroperoxidase antibody
  • Anti Tg – Antithyroglobulin antibody
  • TRBAb – TSH receptor blocking antibodies

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl, a known case of celiac disease, presented to the pediatric endocrine clinic with a history of neck swelling, tremor, and weight loss. On evaluation, she was found to have Graves’ disease. Other conditions that need to be screened in this patient include all of the following except __________.
questions.solution:
Type 2 Diabetes mellitus is not associated with Grave's disease.

Conditions associated with Grave's disease (autoimmune diseases): 

  • Diabetes mellitus type 1
  • Pernicious anaemia
  • Celiac disease
  • Vitiligo
  • Addison disease
  • Alopecia areata
  • Myasthenia gravis

questions.text: An 11-year-old girl was brought by her parents with complaints of weight loss, increased appetite, and a decline in scholastic performance. Following investigations, a diagnosis of Grave’s disease is made. Which of the following is the drug of choice for initial therapy?
questions.solution:
Methimazole is the initial drug of choice for treating Grave's disease (hyperthyroidism) in children.

Option A: Propylthiouracil is not recommended in children because it is associated with fatal hepatotoxicity.

Option C: Radioactive iodine is not preferred as the first-line treatment in hyperthyroidism for children.

Option D: Levothyroxine is used to treat hypothyroidism.

questions.text: Your unit chief has asked you to present the case of a teenager, who was admitted for evaluation of mental retardation, deaf-mutism and a gait disturbance. He also has a significant patellar clonus. On general exam, you note a goitre but according to lab reports, he is apparently euthyroid. His pubertal development has also been normal. The most likely diagnosis is _______.
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of a euthyroid patient with goitre as well as mental retardation, deaf-mutism, and normal pubertal development points towards neurological endemic cretinism.

Endemic cretinism includes 2 different, but overlapping, syndromes: neurologic type and myxedematous type. It is essentially the same disorder, phenotypically modified by the length and severity of postnatal hypothyroidism. Neurological manifestations are interpreted as reflecting the effects of maternal and fetal hypothyroxinemia, secondary to severe iodine deficiency, on the developing nervous system. Both neurologic and myxedematous type can manifest neurologic symptoms. 

Although neurological cretins are euthyroid, linear growth arrest lines in the long bones are often demonstrated radiologically, suggesting previous hypothyroidism.

 

Option B: Graves disease includes a triad of hyperthyroidism with goitre, ophthalmopathy, and dermopathy (no mental retardation, deafness, or pyramidal signs).

Option C: Pendred Syndrome is caused by a mutation in chloride–iodide transporter in thyroid and cochlea resulting in euthyroid/hypothyroid goitre and sensorineural hearing loss (pyramidal signs like clonus are not seen).

Related Pearl: Differences between the two types of endemic cretinism

Neurological type Myxedematous type
Goiter  No goiter (USG shows thyroid atrophy)
Euthyroid  Permanent hypothyroidism
Intellectual disability, deaf-mutism, squint, proximal spasticity, and rigidity Intellectual disability, Deaf, coarse facial features, and myxedema.
Normal pubertal development and adult stature Delayed skeletal maturation and sexual development, severe short stature

questions.text: During a health outreach program in Sikkim, you come across 3 children from the same family, with goiter. Endemic cretinism was suspected. Which of the following can be a manifestation of this condition?
questions.solution:
Strabismus and spastic diplegias are among the manifestations of the neurological type of endemic cretinism.

Cretinism is a condition characterized by irreversible abnormalities in intellectual development. Endemic cretinism occurs due to the nutritional deficiency of iodine. It can be neurological cretinism or myxedematous cretinism. It is associated with severe, irreversible mental retardation.

Related Pearl: Differences between the two types of endemic cretinism

Neurological type Myxedematous type
Goiter  No goiter (USG shows thyroid atrophy)
Euthyroid  Permanent hypothyroidism
